title: SB 1.19.4 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 03-05-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: The king accepted this as good news, for it would be the cause of his indifference toward worldly things.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse and explains how King Pariksit welcomed the news of his imminent death as a means to detach from worldly affairs.

segments.key_quote: One can stop the repetition of birth and death only by going back to Godhead.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the nature of material existence as a cycle of birth and death, contrasting it with spiritual existence and the possibility of returning to Godhead.

segments.key_quote: One can stop the repetition of birth and death only by going back to Godhead.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the meaning of 'going back to Godhead' and mentions Srila Prabhupada's 'Back to Godhead' magazine, emphasizing that even attaining Brahma Loka doesn't free one from the cycle of birth and death.

segments.key_quote: Therefore those who are materially poverty are better candidates than those who are materially prosperous.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the limitations of even the highest material planets in escaping birth and death, highlighting the importance of detachment and the path of perfection, suggesting that material poverty can be an advantage.

segments.key_quote: Material prosperity is like a fever.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of fever to explain that material prosperity is a diseased condition, emphasizing the need to detach from worldly affairs and highlighting how the curse on Pariksit Maharaj was a blessing in disguise, prompting him to renounce his kingdom and prepare for death.

segments.key_quote: Both Shamika Muni and the king were self-realized souls.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Shamika Muni's role in conveying the news of the curse to King Pariksit, emphasizing that both were self-realized souls, not afraid of death, and that Pariksit Maharaj understood the situation and decided to prepare for his imminent death.
The speaker concludes by stating that Pariksit's immediate concern became to prepare himself to go back to Godhead and hints at future verses that will explain how he prepared.
